title: Banned for playing Ascension differently?

embed.description: Being on the Red Team = FeelsBadMan Thanks for all the subs, likes, comments and shares! Helps me a lot!

body:
So apparently, these 5 premade players got their accounts banned for intentional feeding, but these reports came from the enemy team that got tilted from playing against that for almost an hour. Basically, they played a game of Ascension (if you aren't living under a rock you would know of the gamemode riot is pumping out every week) where they would force the enemy team to surrender because they couldn't go back to base to buy items. The premade basically stopped the enemy from capturing relics with Sunfire Capes and them being too tanky to kill after a while. Watch the video for more information. I constantly play Ascension to rack up IP and play stupid shit against real people, and when i saw this strategy I wanted to play in a premade 5 and try it out. But now I'm not so sure that I should because me or my friends may get banned. The links below are ban notifications to the 5 of them.



https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/195463568089546752/344561181446635520/nR_XukOdToq4C3EfFxsgPQ.png
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/195463568089546752/344561188484415488/buV739O9QsWdRDVSeTOBkQ.png
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/195463568089546752/344561190053216256/YbNmr3AQRYKBuSIdv15dSA.png
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/195463568089546752/344561193203007498/neMXpxrRSt2-fWukX3E8Nw.png
https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/195463568089546752/344561199028895744/v5b0ffzlRo_Z64It4cbYLA.pngï»¿






Edit: I personally understand that these player were sort of "held hostage" but in all honesty they chose to continue trying to capture relics instead of just FF@25 or sometime there. I would assume they understood that the game would drag on and they knew that they weren't going to be able to capture relics. In my (silver 1) opinion this is almost the same as playing against someone who counter jg's you and hides in bushes forcibly tilting you hard. Or laning against Darius. And let's not forget the amount of bots that flood into these Ascension games in the first place. If these gamemodes are supposed to be short then enforce it. You could put a limit of how long a game is supposed to be like in the practice tool.

Or you could put other gamemodes back on the rotation.

cough One for All cough Black Market Brawlers

I think people are missing the point here. Is this strategy cancerous? Of course it is because it completely gets rid of any meaningful progress in this game mode, but is it ban worthy? Not really, at least not at this point. If these guys had played 10 or 20 games of this and potentially hindered the enjoyment of 50 to 100 players then I could see it, but just a few games worth should have warranted a warning sent out to each of these players stating exactly why they were in trouble.

Riot should have directly addressed this issue and worked on a hotfix or disable the queue until they are able to patch it. This leads us to the real question. Why did Riot need to ban these players when the responsibility for this oversight is Riots? A ban fixes this for a small group of players, but has opened the strategy up for thousands of players to abuse, which is going to create a massive influx of games that are ruined.

I don't really think this strategy should be allowed, but to ban someone (let alone a group of people) for finding an exploit in your own system that you advertise as pretty much perfect is ignorant at best.

Also please don't come at me with stuff like "Remember Jordan Belfort? He did this exact thing in real life and we all think he should have been thrown in jail!!??" because that isn't a comparable situation. Stealing millions =/= bringing to light an exploit in a rotating game mode. If anything, Riot banning these people and bringing it to the front page of their forums makes them more comparable to Jordan Belfort than the offenders themselves. Both Belfort and Riot are (were) hindering millions of people with their decisions.
